questions.question: Detection of cancer at early stages includes:
questions.explanation: Cancer detection techniques include: biopsy and histopathological examination, blood tests for cancer markers, imaging (X-ray, CT, MRI, PET scan), and molecular techniques.

questions.question: The most important tumor suppressor gene is:
questions.explanation: p53 is called 'guardian of the genome' and is the most commonly mutated gene in human cancers. It regulates cell cycle, DNA repair, and apoptosis. Mutations in p53 are found in >50% of cancers.

questions.question: Ascariasis is caused by:
questions.explanation: Ascariasis is caused by Ascaris lumbricoides, a large roundworm parasitizing the intestine. It spreads through contaminated water, vegetables, and fruits. Causes internal bleeding, muscular pain, blockage.

questions.question: Drugs are defined as:
options: Chemicals that affect body function when taken
questions.explanation: Drugs are chemicals that interact with biological targets in the body to produce physiological effects. They include medicines, recreational substances, and substances of abuse.

questions.question: The window period for HIV is:
options: Time for virus to enter the body
Time between infection and detectable antibodies
questions.explanation: Window period (typically 2-6 weeks) is the time between HIV infection and the appearance of detectable antibodies in blood. During this time, ELISA may give false negative results.

questions.question: Colostrum is rich in:
questions.explanation: Colostrum (first milk) is rich in IgA antibodies which provide protection against gut infections in newborns. This is why early breastfeeding is essential for infant immunity.

questions.question: Which of the following is a physical carcinogen?
questions.explanation: Physical carcinogens include ionizing radiations (X-rays, gamma rays) and non-ionizing radiations (UV rays). They cause DNA damage leading to mutations and cancer.

questions.question: Cancer-causing agents are called:
questions.explanation: Carcinogens are agents that cause cancer. They can be physical (radiation, UV), chemical (tobacco smoke, asbestos), or biological (certain viruses like HPV, hepatitis B).

questions.question: The chemical released during allergic reaction causing symptoms is:
questions.explanation: Histamine is released from mast cells during allergic reactions. It causes vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, smooth muscle contraction, and inflammation - leading to allergic symptoms.

questions.question: Drug addiction is characterized by:
options: Compulsive drug-seeking behavior despite harmful consequences
questions.explanation: Drug addiction (substance use disorder) is characterized by compulsive drug seeking, continued use despite harmful consequences, inability to control use, and withdrawal symptoms on stopping.

questions.question: Allergies are due to:
options: Exaggerated immune response to certain antigens
questions.explanation: Allergies are exaggerated immune responses to normally harmless substances (allergens) like pollen, dust mites, animal dander, or food. IgE antibodies mediate allergic reactions.

questions.question: Pneumonia is caused by:
questions.explanation: Pneumonia is primarily caused by bacteria Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae. It affects the alveoli of lungs, filling them with fluid and reducing respiratory capacity.

questions.question: The vector for elephantiasis is:
questions.explanation: Female Culex mosquito is the vector for elephantiasis (filariasis). It transmits the microfilariae (larval stage) of Wuchereria during blood meal.

questions.question: Viruses that can cause cancer are called:
questions.explanation: Oncogenic (tumor-causing) viruses include HPV (cervical cancer), Hepatitis B and C (liver cancer), EBV (Burkitt's lymphoma), and HTLV-1 (T-cell leukemia).

questions.question: The antibody class involved in allergic reactions is:
questions.explanation: IgE antibodies are involved in allergic reactions. They bind to mast cells and basophils. On re-exposure to allergen, IgE triggers release of histamine and other chemicals causing allergic symptoms.

questions.question: Which cells are called 'soldiers' of the immune system?
questions.explanation: White blood cells (leukocytes) are called soldiers of immune system as they defend against pathogens. They include neutrophils, lymphocytes, monocytes, eosinophils, and basophils.

questions.question: Prevention of drug abuse includes:
options: Education, counseling, family support, avoiding peer pressure
questions.explanation: Prevention strategies include: education about drug effects, building strong family bonds, counseling, peer education programs, avoiding bad company, developing healthy coping mechanisms.

questions.question: B-lymphocytes produce:
questions.explanation: B-lymphocytes (B-cells) produce antibodies (immunoglobulins) and are responsible for humoral immunity. They differentiate into plasma cells that secrete antibodies specific to antigens.

questions.question: Ringworm is caused by:
questions.explanation: Ringworm is a fungal infection (not caused by worms) caused by Microsporum, Trichophyton, and Epidermophyton fungi. It appears as dry, scaly lesions with ring-like appearance on skin, nails, scalp.

questions.question: A person is considered to have AIDS when:
options: T-helper cell count falls below 200 per cubic mm
questions.explanation: AIDS is diagnosed when HIV-positive person's CD4+ T-helper cell count falls below 200 cells/mm³ (normal: 500-1500/mm³) and/or they develop opportunistic infections.

questions.question: AIDS is caused by:
questions.explanation: AIDS (Acquired Immuno Deficiency Syndrome) is caused by HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus), a retrovirus. HIV attacks helper T-cells (CD4+ cells), weakening the immune system.

questions.question: Malaria is caused by:
questions.explanation: Malaria is caused by Plasmodium species (protozoan parasites). Different species cause different types of malaria: P. vivax (benign tertian), P. falciparum (malignant tertian), P. malariae (quartan).

questions.question: Cirrhosis is:
options: Liver disease due to chronic alcohol consumption
questions.explanation: Cirrhosis is chronic liver damage characterized by fibrosis and scarring. Chronic alcohol consumption is a major cause. It leads to liver failure, portal hypertension, and is irreversible.

questions.question: Metastasis is:
options: Spread of cancer cells to distant body parts
questions.explanation: Metastasis is the spread of cancer cells from primary tumor to distant body parts through blood or lymphatic system. It is a hallmark of malignant tumors and makes cancer difficult to treat.

questions.question: Diseases that can be transmitted from one person to another are called:
questions.explanation: Communicable or infectious diseases can spread from infected person to healthy person through various modes like air, water, contact, vectors, etc. Examples: typhoid, tuberculosis, common cold.

questions.question: Cocaine is obtained from:
questions.explanation: Cocaine is obtained from leaves of coca plant (Erythroxylum coca). It is a powerful CNS stimulant that interferes with dopamine transport, causing intense euphoria and high addiction potential.

questions.question: HIV belongs to the group:
questions.explanation: HIV is a retrovirus - an RNA virus that uses reverse transcriptase enzyme to convert its RNA to DNA, which then integrates into the host cell's genome.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a barrier of innate immunity?
questions.explanation: Antibodies are part of acquired (adaptive) immunity, not innate immunity. Innate immunity includes physical barriers (skin, mucous), chemical barriers (lysozyme in tears, HCl in stomach), and cellular barriers.

questions.question: Contact inhibition refers to:
options: Normal cells stopping division on contact with other cells
questions.explanation: Contact inhibition is the property of normal cells to stop dividing when they contact neighboring cells. Cancer cells lose this property and continue dividing, forming tumors.

questions.question: Alcohol primarily affects:
questions.explanation: Alcohol (ethanol) primarily affects the CNS (depressant) and liver (causes cirrhosis). It also damages pancreas, heart, and brain with chronic use. It crosses placenta and causes fetal alcohol syndrome.

questions.question: Cannabinoids are derived from:
questions.explanation: Cannabinoids (marijuana, hashish, charas, ganja) are derived from Cannabis sativa (hemp plant). THC (tetrahydrocannabinol) is the main psychoactive component affecting cardiovascular system.

questions.question: Heroin is derived from:
questions.explanation: Heroin (diacetyl morphine/diamorphine) is derived from morphine, which comes from the latex of poppy plant (Papaver somniferum). It is highly addictive and is a depressant.

questions.question: Benign tumors:
options: Remain confined and do not spread
questions.explanation: Benign tumors remain confined to their original location, do not invade surrounding tissues or metastasize. They are generally not life-threatening and can be removed surgically.

questions.question: LSD (Lysergic acid diethylamide) is a:
questions.explanation: LSD is a powerful hallucinogen derived from ergot fungus (Claviceps purpurea). It causes hallucinations, altered perception, and psychological effects. Not physically addictive but psychologically dangerous.

questions.question: Autoimmunity occurs when:
options: Immune system attacks body's own cells
questions.explanation: Autoimmunity occurs when the immune system fails to distinguish self from non-self and attacks body's own cells. Examples: rheumatoid arthritis, multiple sclerosis, type 1 diabetes.

questions.question: Typhoid fever is caused by:
questions.explanation: Typhoid fever is caused by the bacterium Salmonella typhi. It spreads through contaminated food and water. Widal test is used for diagnosis. Mary Mallon (Typhoid Mary) was a famous carrier.

questions.question: Elephantiasis (filariasis) is caused by:
questions.explanation: Elephantiasis is caused by Wuchereria bancrofti and W. malayi (filarial worms). The adult worms live in lymphatic vessels, blocking lymph flow and causing swelling of limbs (especially legs), scrotum.

questions.question: Health is defined by WHO as:
options: State of complete physical, mental and social well-being
questions.explanation: WHO defines health as 'a state of complete physical, mental and social well-being and not merely the absence of disease or infirmity'. This holistic definition includes all aspects of well-being.

questions.question: Immunity present from birth is called:
questions.explanation: Innate (inborn/natural) immunity is present from birth. It includes physical barriers (skin, mucous membranes), physiological barriers (pH, temperature), cellular barriers (WBCs), and cytokine barriers.

questions.question: Opioids include:
questions.explanation: Opioids are drugs derived from or related to opium. They include morphine, heroin (diacetyl morphine), codeine, and synthetic opioids. They bind to opioid receptors and cause euphoria, pain relief.

questions.question: Acquired immunity that develops after exposure to antigen is called:
questions.explanation: Active immunity develops when the body's own immune system responds to antigen exposure (natural infection or vaccination). It involves production of antibodies and memory cells, providing long-lasting protection.

questions.question: Vaccination provides:
questions.explanation: Vaccination provides active immunity by exposing the body to weakened/killed pathogens or their products (antigens). This stimulates antibody production and memory cell formation without causing disease.

questions.question: Amoebic dysentery (amoebiasis) is caused by:
questions.explanation: Amoebiasis or amoebic dysentery is caused by Entamoeba histolytica. It spreads through contaminated food and water. Symptoms include constipation, abdominal pain, bloody stools with mucus.

questions.question: Which of the following diseases has been eradicated through vaccination?
questions.explanation: Smallpox was declared eradicated by WHO in 1980, the first disease to be completely eliminated through vaccination. India was declared smallpox-free in 1975.

questions.question: Rheumatoid arthritis is an example of:
questions.explanation: Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disease where the immune system attacks joint tissues, causing inflammation, pain, and joint destruction. It commonly affects hands and feet.

questions.question: Primary immune response is:
options: Slow and weak, produces memory cells
questions.explanation: Primary immune response occurs on first antigen exposure. It is slow (lag period of 5-10 days), produces low antibody levels, but generates memory B and T cells for future responses.

questions.question: Tumor suppressor genes:
options: Inhibit cell division and prevent cancer
questions.explanation: Tumor suppressor genes (anti-oncogenes) inhibit cell proliferation and promote apoptosis. Loss of function mutations in these genes (like p53, Rb) can lead to cancer development.

questions.question: Ringworm spreads through:
options: Soil, towels, clothes, and comb of infected persons
questions.explanation: Ringworm spreads through contact with infected soil or by using towels, clothes, or combs of infected persons. Heat and moisture help in fungal growth, common in groin, feet, and scalp.

questions.question: The diagnostic test for HIV infection is:
questions.explanation: ELISA (Enzyme Linked Immunosorbent Assay) is the primary screening test for HIV. It detects HIV antibodies in blood. Western blot is used as confirmatory test.

questions.question: The infective stage of Plasmodium transmitted by mosquito to human is:
questions.explanation: Sporozoites are the infective stage of Plasmodium transmitted from mosquito to human during blood meal. They travel to liver where they multiply before entering RBCs.

questions.question: Chemical carcinogens include:
questions.explanation: Chemical carcinogens include tobacco smoke components, asbestos (causes mesothelioma), aflatoxins (from Aspergillus, causes liver cancer), benzene, vinyl chloride, and many others.

questions.question: Genes that normally stimulate cell division are called:
questions.explanation: Proto-oncogenes are normal genes that promote cell growth and division. When mutated or overexpressed, they become oncogenes and can cause cancer by promoting uncontrolled cell division.

questions.question: The structure of antibody molecule is:
questions.explanation: Antibodies are Y-shaped molecules made of 4 polypeptide chains: 2 identical heavy chains and 2 identical light chains linked by disulfide bonds. The Y arms have antigen-binding sites.

questions.question: Lysozyme present in tears and saliva:
questions.explanation: Lysozyme is an antibacterial enzyme present in tears, saliva, nasal secretions, and breast milk. It destroys bacterial cell walls by hydrolyzing peptidoglycan, providing innate immune protection.

questions.question: Secondary immune response is characterized by:
options: Quick, strong response due to memory cells
questions.explanation: Secondary (anamnestic) response occurs on subsequent antigen exposure. Memory cells enable quick (no lag), intense response with high antibody levels. This is the basis of vaccination.

questions.question: HIV primarily attacks:
questions.explanation: HIV specifically attacks helper T-cells (CD4+ T-lymphocytes), macrophages, and dendritic cells that have CD4 receptors. Loss of T-helper cells severely compromises immune function.

questions.question: The confirmatory test for typhoid is:
questions.explanation: Widal test is the serological test used for diagnosis of typhoid fever. It detects antibodies against Salmonella typhi antigens (O and H antigens) in patient's serum.

questions.question: Malignant tumors are characterized by:
questions.explanation: Malignant tumors (cancers) grow rapidly, invade surrounding tissues, and can metastasize (spread) to distant body parts through blood or lymph. They are life-threatening.

questions.question: The causative organism of plague is:
questions.explanation: Plague (Black Death) is caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis. It is transmitted by rat fleas and can cause bubonic, pneumonic, or septicemic plague. It caused devastating epidemics in history.

questions.question: The characteristic fever pattern in malaria is caused by:
options: Release of merozoites and haemozoin from RBCs
questions.explanation: Malarial fever occurs when infected RBCs rupture, releasing merozoites and toxic waste (haemozoin). This triggers high fever with chills. The cycle repeats every 48-72 hours depending on species.

questions.question: In pneumonia, the alveoli get filled with:
questions.explanation: In pneumonia, the alveoli become filled with fluid and cell debris, reducing gas exchange efficiency. This causes severe breathing problems due to decreased respiratory surface area.

questions.question: Cancer is characterized by:
questions.explanation: Cancer is characterized by uncontrolled, abnormal cell proliferation. Cancer cells lose contact inhibition, divide continuously, and can spread to other body parts (metastasis).

questions.question: Immunity obtained through antibodies from mother is:
questions.explanation: Passive immunity is obtained by receiving ready-made antibodies from another individual. Maternal antibodies pass to fetus (IgG via placenta) and infant (IgA via colostrum). It provides immediate but temporary protection.

questions.question: Edward Jenner is known for:
questions.explanation: Edward Jenner developed the first vaccine in 1796 against smallpox using cowpox virus. He observed that milkmaids who had cowpox were protected from smallpox, leading to vaccination.

questions.question: Adolescents are more vulnerable to drug abuse due to:
questions.explanation: Adolescents are vulnerable to drug abuse due to peer pressure, curiosity, desire to experiment, emotional instability, stress, and need for acceptance. Brain development makes them susceptible to addiction.

questions.question: Interferons are used in cancer treatment because they:
options: Activate immune system against cancer cells
questions.explanation: Interferons are cytokines that activate immune cells (NK cells, macrophages) to destroy cancer cells. Alpha-interferon is used in treatment of certain cancers and viral infections.

questions.question: Plasmodium reproduces asexually in:
questions.explanation: Plasmodium reproduces asexually in human host (schizogony in liver and RBCs) and sexually in mosquito (gametogony and sporogony). Human is the intermediate host, mosquito is the definitive host.

questions.question: Treatment of cancer includes:
questions.explanation: Cancer treatment includes surgery (tumor removal), radiation therapy (kills cancer cells), chemotherapy (cytotoxic drugs), immunotherapy (activating immune system), and targeted therapy.

questions.question: Common cold is caused by:
questions.explanation: Common cold is caused by rhinoviruses - a group of RNA viruses. It infects the nose, respiratory passage and spreads through droplets (coughs, sneezes) or contaminated objects.

questions.question: Interferon is:
options: Antiviral protein produced by virus-infected cells
questions.explanation: Interferons are antiviral proteins produced by virus-infected cells. They 'interfere' with viral replication and also activate immune cells. They are used in treatment of viral infections and some cancers.

questions.question: T-lymphocytes are responsible for:
questions.explanation: T-lymphocytes (T-cells) mediate cell-mediated immunity (CMI). They directly attack infected cells, cancer cells, and transplanted tissues. T-helper cells also assist B-cells in antibody production.

questions.question: Tobacco contains the addictive substance:
questions.explanation: Tobacco contains nicotine, a highly addictive stimulant that increases dopamine levels in the brain. Tobacco smoke also contains carcinogens like benzopyrene and carbon monoxide.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT transmitted by contaminated needles?
questions.explanation: Malaria is transmitted by mosquito bite, not contaminated needles. HIV, Hepatitis B, and Hepatitis C can all be transmitted through sharing contaminated needles among intravenous drug users.

questions.question: Antibodies are also called:
questions.explanation: Antibodies are also called immunoglobulins (Ig). They are glycoprotein molecules produced by plasma cells in response to antigens. Five classes: IgG, IgA, IgM, IgE, and IgD.

questions.question: HIV spreads through:
options: Sexual contact, blood transfusion, contaminated needles
questions.explanation: HIV spreads through: unprotected sexual contact, contaminated blood transfusion, sharing needles (drug users), mother to child (during pregnancy, delivery, or breastfeeding). Not through casual contact.

questions.question: The vector for malaria is:
questions.explanation: Female Anopheles mosquito is the vector for malaria. The mosquito transmits Plasmodium sporozoites during blood meal. Only females bite as they need blood for egg development.

questions.question: Smoking can cause:
questions.explanation: Smoking causes multiple diseases: lung cancer and other cancers, emphysema, chronic bronchitis, coronary heart disease, stroke, and oral cancers. It is the leading preventable cause of death.

questions.question: Immunosuppression occurs in AIDS because:
options: Helper T-cells are destroyed by HIV
questions.explanation: HIV specifically destroys CD4+ helper T-cells which coordinate immune responses. Without T-helper cells, both humoral and cell-mediated immunity are severely compromised, leading to immunosuppression.

questions.question: Oncogenes are:
questions.explanation: Oncogenes are mutated or overexpressed forms of proto-oncogenes that promote cancer development. They stimulate uncontrolled cell proliferation. Examples: ras, myc, src.
